snippet: The Federal Reserve has spent heavily to buy bonds to reduce long-term rates, but rates are actually higher than when it started.
abstract: Anna Bernasek Data Points column notes that Federal Reserve has spent $800 billion buying bonds since Sept 2012 to reduce long-term rates, but rates are actually higher than when it started; points out that for that money Fed could have given every homeowner in nation $10,000 loan at near-zero rate of interest, with greater economic benefit.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve has spent heavily to buy bonds to reduce long-term rates, but rates are actually higher than when it started.

headline.main: What the Nation Got for $800 Billion
headline.print_headline: What the Nation Got For $800 Billion
